Stream: learning: questions

Topic: Hints for Leinster's "Basic Category Theory" exercises

Ryan Schwiebert (Jul 13 2024 at 00:13):

This is exercise 2.1.16

Let G be a group considered as a category and [G,Set] be the category of functors from G to Set (a.k.a left G-sets). What interesting functors are there between Set and [G,Set]? which if any are adjoint to each other?

I get how open ended questions like this can be beneficial but I also hate how easy it would be to completely miss intended insights.

The only candidates I spotted are the functor (call it U) which "forgets" its G action. and just returns the underlying set, and in the other direction, the functor that imbues any set with the trivial G action, call it T.

I'm still trying to puzzle out whether or not they're adjoint in one order or the other, but firstly I just wanted to ask what, if any, other functors I am missing.

By the way, is there some trick to spot which order they might be adjoint in? Since free -| forgetful, one might wonder if U is the right adjoint. But free functors for algebras seem like they are "elaborating" and the trivial action is kind of a dumbing-down, so maybe it goes on the right.

Or I could be completely off and they're not adjoint in any way :/ But since any set function can be regarded as a G-equivariant map between two sets with trivial G actions, it seems like it is an adjoint relationship.

Your input is appreciated!

David Egolf (Jul 13 2024 at 01:08):

When trying to think of more functors between Set\mathsf{Set}Set and [G,Set][G, \mathsf{Set}][G,Set], the first question that comes to mind for me is this: What are the representable functors from [G,Set][G, \mathsf{Set}][G,Set] to Set\mathsf{Set}Set?

If we pick some ρ:G→Set\rho: G \to \mathsf{Set}ρ:G→Set, then what is the functor [G,Set](ρ,−):[G,Set]→Set[G, \mathsf{Set}](\rho, -): [G, \mathsf{Set}] \to \mathsf{Set}[G,Set](ρ,−):[G,Set]→Set? Does this give anything interesting in some special cases, maybe? (In particular, I'm curious what happens in the case where ρ\rhoρ sends each element of GGG to the same identity function).

I don't know if this will be helpful... But after a little bit of searching online (for example, I found this), it seems like there is some connection between a functor being representable and having a left adjoint. So maybe this is relevant!

Kevin Carlson (Jul 13 2024 at 01:29):

I’m not sure how much you know about coproducts, but one good way to find left adjoints out of Sets uses the fact that every set is a coproduct of copies of a one-element set (so the whole left adjoint, since it must preserve coproducts, is determined by where it sends a singleton.)

Kevin Carlson (Jul 13 2024 at 01:31):

As for finding adjoint relationships with functors you’ve already named, just think about the adjunction relationship. What’s a map from a set SSS into some U(X),U(X),U(X), and what about in the other direction? Could you replace it with one involving some GGG-action related to SSS?

David Egolf (Jul 13 2024 at 03:40):

Ryan Schwiebert said:

David Egolf said:

I think what you're describing is "giving X the trivial G action," the functor T I proposed.

I'm interested in the case where ρ\rhoρ specifies a trivial action. I think more specifically I'm curious what [G,Set](ρ,−):[G,Set]→Set[G, \mathsf{Set}](\rho, -):[G,\mathsf{Set}] \to \mathsf{Set}[G,Set](ρ,−):[G,Set]→Set is like when ρ:G→Set\rho:G \to \mathsf{Set}ρ:G→Set is acting on a set with a single element.

Let ∗*∗ be the single object of GGG, when GGG is viewed as a category. When ρ\rhoρ acts on a singleton set, ρ(∗)\rho(*)ρ(∗) is a singleton set. Further, in this case a natural transformation from ρ\rhoρ to some ρ′:G→Set\rho': G \to \mathsf{Set}ρ′:G→Set amounts to a function α∗:ρ(∗)→ρ′(∗)\alpha_*: \rho(*) \to \rho'(*)α∗​:ρ(∗)→ρ′(∗) such that this square commutes for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G:
naturality square

A function from ρ(∗)\rho(*)ρ(∗) to ρ′(∗)\rho'(*)ρ′(∗) amounts to choosing an element of ρ′(∗)\rho'(*)ρ′(∗), because ρ(∗)\rho(*)ρ(∗) has only one element. So, a natural transformation from ρ\rhoρ to ρ′\rho'ρ′ I think amounts to the choice of an element of ρ′(∗)\rho'(*)ρ′(∗) that doesn't change when acted on by any element in GGG, using the action ρ′\rho'ρ′.

Building on this, the set of natural transformations from ρ\rhoρ to ρ′\rho'ρ′, namely [G,Set](ρ,ρ′)[G,\mathsf{Set}](\rho, \rho')[G,Set](ρ,ρ′), I think is in bijection with the set {x∈ρ′(∗)∣ρ′(g)(x)=x for all g∈G}\{x \in \rho'(*) | \rho'(g)(x)=x \textrm{ for all } g \in G\}{x∈ρ′(∗)∣ρ′(g)(x)=x for all g∈G}.

If I didn't make a mistake, it seems like there is a functor [G,Set](ρ,−):[G,Set]→Set[G, \mathsf{Set}](\rho, -): [G, \mathsf{Set}] \to \mathsf{Set}[G,Set](ρ,−):[G,Set]→Set that sends each group action ρ′\rho'ρ′ (acting on some set ρ′(∗)\rho'(*)ρ′(∗)) to the set of elements (of ρ′(∗)\rho'(*)ρ′(∗)) that are invariant under that action.

John Baez (Jul 13 2024 at 06:21):

Ryan Schwiebert said:

I read that question and thought: "oh, Leinster is trying to get people to think about the forgetful functor sending each G-set to its underlying set and the functor sending each set to the free G-set on that set, and show they're adjoints to each other". I believe this is what should flash through the mind of any category theorist in the first second after reading this question. Then there are other things to do, like check if these functors really are adjoint, and look for others.

I wonder if at this point in his book Leinster has mentioned that the words "underlying" or "forgetful" should scream out RIGHT ADJOINT!!! and the word "free" should scream out LEFT ADJOINT!!!

John Baez (Jul 14 2024 at 07:47):

Kevin Carlson said:

Clearly neither of us want to give away all the details of we're really talking about here, so as not to spoil Ryan's fun. I still think it's a useful to have a sense of smell, so that you walk into an adjunction and instantly have a sense of who is the right adjoint and who is the left adjoint. But then you learn that a right adjoint can have its own right adjoint, which Lawvere called a 'far-right' or 'fascist' functor.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) (Jul 15 2024 at 08:53):

I actually think that Leinster was trying to appeal to the intuition of a reader who has taken a course in group theory here! From that perspective, there is a functor "more obvious" than fixed points that goes from left GGG-sets to sets!
I don't know if this was @Oscar Cunningham 's "fifth functor", but I feel entitled to hint that I expect the list of functors that Leinster was expecting you to come up with should have six functors in it :wink:

David Egolf (Jul 16 2024 at 16:51):

I was curious about how one could think up the functor that sends a group action to its set of orbits. I found this interesting quote from "Category Theory in Context" (p. 108):

The limit of a functor X:BG→SetX : \mathsf{B}G → \mathsf{Set}X:BG→Set is the set of GGG-fixed points... and the colimit is the set of GGG-orbits... .

We obtain functors by taking these limits or colimits, as indicated by these statements (see here, for example):

  • Given a category of DDD-shaped diagrams [D,C][D,C][D,C], there is a functor :[D,C]→C:[D, C] \to C:[D,C]→C that takes the limit of each diagram, provided those limits exist in CCC.
  • Similarly, given a category of DDD-shaped diagrams [D,C][D,C][D,C], there is a functor :[D,C]→C:[D, C] \to C:[D,C]→C that takes the colimit of each diagram, provided those colimits exist in CCC.

If I had thought to explore these general statements in the context of this exercise, presumably I would have discovered the functor that sends a group action to its set of orbits!

Oscar Cunningham (Jul 16 2024 at 20:25):

The other way you could think it up is by finding it as an adjoint to one of the other functors.

John Baez (Jul 17 2024 at 12:46):

Yes, it's all the functors on your list of functors going between Set\mathsf{Set}Set and [G,Set][G,\mathsf{Set}][G,Set] and for each one either find both a left and a right adjoint, or prove some of these adjoints don't exist. (The latter is usually easy by finding a colimit or limit that the functor doesn't preserve.)

John Baez (Jul 24 2024 at 09:04):

Ryan Schwiebert said:

Well, I have to give up, since I think I'm again approaching the border between "let's struggle with it" and "ragequit." I just can't intuit the correct combination of action and transpose.

I had thought that the correct action for XGX^GXG would be, given f:G→Xf:G\to Xf:G→X and h∈Gh\in Gh∈G, the map h⋅fh\cdot fh⋅f given by (h⋅f)(g)=f(hg)(h\cdot f)(g)=f(hg)(h⋅f)(g)=f(hg)

This formula doesn't make XGX^GXG into a left GGG-set, since it obeys

h⋅(h′⋅f)=(h′h)⋅f h \cdot ( h' \cdot f) = (h' h) \cdot f h⋅(h′⋅f)=(h′h)⋅f

rather than

h⋅(h′⋅f)=(hh′)⋅f h \cdot ( h' \cdot f) = (h h' ) \cdot f h⋅(h′⋅f)=(hh′)⋅f

You're instead getting a right GGG-set. If you're shooting for a left GGG-set - and I seem to recall we're working with left GGG-sets in this conversation - then I think there are two ways to do it.

John Baez (Jul 24 2024 at 09:08):

There's a total of four formulas you could try:

1) (h⋅f)(g)=f(hg) (h \cdot f)(g) = f(h g) (h⋅f)(g)=f(hg)

2) (h⋅f)(g)=f(h−1g) (h \cdot f)(g) = f(h^{-1} g) (h⋅f)(g)=f(h−1g)

3) (h⋅f)(g)=f(gh) (h \cdot f)(g) = f(g h) (h⋅f)(g)=f(gh)

4) (h⋅f)(g)=f(gh−1) (h \cdot f)(g) = f(g h^{-1})(h⋅f)(g)=f(gh−1)

John Baez (Jul 24 2024 at 09:09):

It looks like you tried 1) and 2), though there's a typo in your second try.

John Baez (Jul 24 2024 at 12:01):

This stuff about left and right actions always offers plenty of scope for getting confused. In fact any group has 3 left actions on itself and 3 right actions, not counting trivial actions. (The kind we're not concerned with here involve conjugation.)

John Baez (Jul 25 2024 at 07:07):

I guess I'm asking for a hint: is this latter adjunction supposed to work? Or am I totally off base with the ideas above?

I don't really know; I'd have to think about it. I just find it hard to believe that the two chains of adjunctions you've found so far don't link together. You say that Set and [G,Set] are "fairly pure" categories but that's a ridiculous understatement: they are exceptional jewels in the firmament of mathematics, among the best things in the universe, so we should expect that everything works out wonderfully well.

I could throw around some jargon and say we're dealing with an essential geometric morphism between Boolean presheaf categories. Basically this means we're in a situation that's really famous for having interesting long-ish chains of adjoint functors. Someone like @Morgan Rogers (he/him) or @Reid Barton could jump in and say a lot more, but they've wisely refrained from doing that, merely giving us a few hints here and there, because they both know it's better if we fiddle around and work out this stuff from scratch, while they watch us and smile knowingly.

John Baez (Jul 25 2024 at 07:09):

Since I'm thinking about fifteen things at a time these days, I tend to forget what you've done unless I see it summarized in a nice little chart. So let me make that chart.

You've got two chains of adjunctions:

F⊣U⊣CF\dashv U \dashv C F⊣U⊣C and O⊣T⊣Φ\mathcal O\dashv T\dashv \PhiO⊣T⊣Φ

so there are two possible ways to glue them together into one really long chain.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) (Jul 25 2024 at 09:33):

I should also note that if you want to show that adjoints to some of these functors don't exist, you need to:

  1. assume that the group is non-trivial, since when the group is trivial [G,Set][G,\mathrm{Set}][G,Set] is equivalent to Set\mathrm{Set}Set and all of the functors we've discussed are naturally isomorphic to the identity
  2. consider some limits and colimits which might fail to be preserved by the respective functors (recalling that left adjoints preserve colimits and right adjoints preserve limits, so failure to preserve these shows that an adjoint cannot exist). To avoid spoilers I'll just say that binary products or coproducts will do for at least one of the examples (but maybe just one :stuck_out_tongue_wink: ), but for another you'll need to consider a coequalizer.

John Baez (Jul 27 2024 at 13:44):

Thanks. So you're looking for a "candidate in the other direction": a recipe which when given an arbitrary function f:X→A/Gf: X \to A/Gf:X→A/G produces a GGG-equivariant map f‾:XG→A\underline{f}: X^G \to Af​:XG→A.

In other words, given an arbitrary function f:X→A/Gf: X \to A/Gf:X→A/G and an arbitrary function h:G→Xh: G \to Xh:G→X we need to produce an element of AAA, which will be called f‾(h)\underline{f}(h)f​(h). And then we need to check that

f‾(gh)=gf‾(h)\underline{f}(g h ) = g \underline{f}(h) f​(gh)=gf​(h)

to show f‾\underline{f}f​ is GGG-equivariant.

John Baez (Jul 27 2024 at 13:46):

As you note, it seems like a severe uphill climb to get an element of AAA out of fff and hhh - it looks bad.

John Baez (Jul 27 2024 at 13:47):

fff and hhh are begging to be composed, and that'll give f∘h:G→A/Gf \circ h: G \to A/Gf∘h:G→A/G. But what use is that?

John Baez (Jul 27 2024 at 13:51):

So this looks bad. But as Morgan was hinting, reasoning of this general sort - fiddling around with the things we can do - can't really prove that a functor has no left adjoint. This sort of reasoning lets us either find the left adjoint if it exists, or convince us that it doesn't exist if we're unable to find it. But to put the nail in the coffin, and show that some functor has no left adjoint, we need to assume our functor has a left adjoint and get a contradiction somehow. (This is legitimate even intuitionistically!) And the simplest way is often to show our functor fails to preserve some colimit.

John Baez (Jul 27 2024 at 17:26):

Good! By the way, I think you've seen a great example of this phenomenon:

Whenever we have a functor between categories f:C→Df: C \to Df:C→D we get a functor

f∗:[D,Set]→[C,Set]f^\ast: [D,\mathsf{Set}] \to [C, \mathsf{Set}] f∗:[D,Set]→[C,Set]

given in the obvious way: given h:D→Seth : D \to \mathsf{Set}h:D→Set we say

f∗(h)=h∘f f^\ast(h) = h \circ f f∗(h)=h∘f

Such a functor f∗:[D,Set]→[C,Set]f^\ast: [D,\mathsf{Set}] \to [C, \mathsf{Set}] f∗:[D,Set]→[C,Set] always has both a left adjoint and a right adjoint!

In particular we can think of a group as a one-object category and apply this idea to groups.

Any group GGG has homomorphisms to and from the trivial group 111, say

i:1→Gi: 1 \to Gi:1→G

and

t:G→1t: G \to 1t:G→1

But [1,Set]≅Set[1,\mathsf{Set}] \cong \mathsf{Set}[1,Set]≅Set. So, we get functors

i∗:[G,Set]→Seti^\ast : [G, \mathsf{Set}] \to \mathsf{Set} i∗:[G,Set]→Set

and

t∗:Set→[G,Set] t^\ast: \mathsf{Set} \to [G, \mathsf{Set}] t∗:Set→[G,Set]

each of which has both a left and a right adjoint.

This accounts for the 6 functors you found, and why they form two separate adjoint strings, each 3 long.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) (Jul 27 2024 at 17:53):

Since Ryan is moving on, it's worth pointing out that the converse is true too: a functor between categories of presheaves on idempotent complete categories is necessarily induced by a functor... which gives another way of deducing whether or not more of the functors are adjoint!

Peva Blanchard (Jul 27 2024 at 20:01):

@David Egolf They relate to left and right Kan extensions (I think). And, if I remember correctly, they are also named ∃f\exists_f∃f​ and ∀f\forall_f∀f​. The reason behind those names is that it also relates to logic. Another interpretation exists in terms of data migration. I have to dig a bit to find the papers I read that from, but @Ryan Wisnesky gave a very good talk at the Zulip CT Seminar.

David Egolf (Jul 27 2024 at 20:13):

Ah, thanks @Peva Blanchard! With the help of your comment, I was able to find the following in "Category Theory in Context" (Proposition 6.1.5):

If, for fixed K:C→DK:C \to DK:C→D and EEE, the left and right Kan extensions of any functor F:C→EF:C \to EF:C→E along KKK exist, then these define left and right adjoints to the pre-composition functor K∗:ED→ECK^*:E^D \to E^CK∗:ED→EC.

John Baez (Jul 27 2024 at 20:42):

Yes, and these particular right and left Kan extensions can be described very explicitly, for example using ends and coends. So you can actually 'compute' them.

Btw, @David Egolf and @Peva Blanchard, I'll talk about one of these adjoints in Topos Theory (Part 4) when I discuss functors between categories of sheaves (which generalize presheaf categories in a sense). The nice kind of map between categories of sheaves is called a 'geometric morphism', and it consists of a functor called the 'inverse image' and its right adjoint, called the 'direct image'.

John Baez (Jul 27 2024 at 20:55):

When the inverse image functor also has a left adjoint, we say we've got an 'essential' geometric morphism.

John Baez (Jul 27 2024 at 20:56):

So, the stuff we've been doing in this thread can be seen as a warmup for topos theory.

John Baez (Aug 08 2024 at 09:04):

An interesting fact is that if a functor LLL has a right adjoint RRR, this fact determines RRR, and you can actually crank out what RRR must be using the natural isomorphism

hom(Lx,y)≅hom(x,Ry) \mathrm{hom}(L x, y) \cong \mathrm{hom}(x, R y) hom(Lx,y)≅hom(x,Ry)

John Baez (Aug 08 2024 at 09:05):

Simply put, this isomorphism lets you figure out what the morphisms from any xxx to RyR yRy are, and this in turn lets you figure out what RyR yRy must be.

John Baez (Aug 08 2024 at 09:09):

So in some sense there's no "creativity" required for determining a right adjoint if one has been told it exists: it's a calculation, not a matter of guesswork. I find this reassuring... though there is creativity required in finding a nice description of the right adjoint.

First something really stupid. Take S=1S = 1S=1. Then the left-hand side has just one element, so the right-hand side must as well, so Δ(S)\Delta(S)Δ(S) must be the terminal presheaf, which happens to be the presheaf that assigns a one-element set to every open U⊆XU \subseteq XU⊆X. So we know Δ(S)\Delta(S)Δ(S) in this one case.

John Baez (Aug 08 2024 at 09:28):

But this is no big surprise: we've just reproved that a right adjoint must send a terminal object to a terminal object.

John Baez (Aug 08 2024 at 09:29):

It's also known that a right adjoint preserves products and equalizers, so we instantly know Δ(S)\Delta(S)Δ(S) for every set built from one-element sets by taking products and equalizers. Unfortunately the only sets we get this way are one-element sets. :sad: So, this is not useful... not yet, anyway.

Chris Grossack (they/them) (Aug 24 2024 at 22:35):

Subsets A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X so that f−1f∗A=Af^{-1} f_* A = Af−1f∗​A=A are often called "saturated". And a subset $$B \sibseteq Y$$ satisfies the dual property exactly when it's contained in the image of fff. So this tells you that subsets of Im(f)\text{Im}(f)Im(f) are in natural bijection with saturated subsets of XXX. In fact, it tells you the lattice structures on these collections are the same!

John Baez (Aug 31 2024 at 01:06):

Ryan Schwiebert said:

I could use some sanity checks on what I think I found. I think the free/forgetful adjunction between Set and Vect, and the adjunction between −×B-\times B−×B and (−)B(-)^B(−)B are not reflections.

That's right. I find it helps to think of a reflection as what you get when you have a category CCC of things, a subcategory NNN of "nice" things that have extra properties, but where maps are defined the same way, and a functor called the reflector L:C→NL: C \to NL:C→N that "makes things be nice" by imposing those extra properties. Part of the deal here is that if you make a thing be nice, and then make it be nice again, it doesn't change the second time, since it's already nice.

The example I always remember is abelian groups as a reflective subcategory of groups. Abelian groups are just groups with an extra property, namely being abelian. So a homomorphism between abelian group is just a group homomorphism between groups that happen to be abelian - that's what I mean by "maps are defined the same way". And the reflector is abelianization. If you abelianize a group that's already abelian, you're not doing anything to it.

This example also helps me remember that the reflector is a left adjoint. In this example, it's left adjoint to the forgetful functor that forgets the abelianness of a group.

None of this is like what's going on between sets and vector spaces! Nobody ever says sets are vector spaces with a nice property, or vector spaces are sets with a nice property. Sure, vector spaces are sets with extra structure - but the maps between them have to preserve that extra structure, they are not just arbitrary functions between sets that happen to be vector spaces.

On the other hand, the free-inclusion and inclusion-(subset of units) between Mon and Grp both seem to be reflections.

That doesn't sound quite right. It's true that groups are just monoids with an extra property. A group homomorphism is just a monoid homomorphism between monoids that happen to be groups. (We don't need to separately say that inverses are preserved - that follows automatically.)

But it sounds like you're claiming the reflector sends any monoid to its group of units: the submonoid consisting of invertible elements. That can't be. Taking the group of units defines a functor from Mon to Grp, but I don't think this is the left adjoint to the forgetful functor Grp →\to→ Mon. I think this is the right adjoint. A reflector needs to be a left adjoint!

Secondly, I'm also trying to reconcile this notion of "reflective subcategory" with "adjunction that is a reflection." I can't quite tell if the same thing is being described in two different ways.

Yes, they are equivalent concepts - two ways of talking about the same phenomenon.

Thirdly, no mention is made of the dual thing with the adjunction, where one could ask the unit is an isomorphism. Does anyone get any mileage out of an "adjunction that is a coreflection"?

It sounds like you're talking about the concept of [[coreflective subcategory]]. There are some examples of those at the link. And in fact one of them is this:

the inclusion of groups into monoids, where the right adjoint takes a monoid to its group of units.

John Baez (Sep 05 2024 at 15:53):

All this notation is confusing me, but when you have a function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y any subset S⊂XS \subset XS⊂X has an image in YYY, but also another thing, less widely discussed, which I'll call the 'dual image'. So we get two maps PX→PYP X \to P YPX→PY, and one of these is the left adjoint of the inverse image map f−1:PY→PXf^{-1}: P Y \to P Xf−1:PY→PX while the other is the right adjoint.

  • The image of S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X is the subset {f(x) ∣  x∈S} \{f(x) \, \vert \; x \in S \}{f(x)∣x∈S}

and

  • The dual image of S⊆XS\subseteq XS⊆X is the complement of the image of the complement of SSS.

John Baez (Sep 05 2024 at 15:57):

A more systematic way to say it, less likely to offend intuitionistic logicians:

  • y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y is in the image of S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X if some element x∈Xx \in Xx∈X with f(x)=yf(x) = yf(x)=y is an element of SSS.

  • y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y is in the dual image of S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X if every element x∈Xx \in Xx∈X with f(x)=yf(x) = yf(x)=y is an element of SSS.

John Baez (Sep 07 2024 at 12:59):

I've circled back to this. Yes, indeed, I've never run across it before.

I don't know a really standard name for this 'dual image' thing: it seems sadly unused. You might use it in computer security or other subjects where you're trying to make things safe, like food or drug manufacture and distribution.

Suppose XXX is some set of things, and S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X is the set of things of type XXX that are 'safe'. Suppose f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y converts things of type XXX to things of type YYY. Then you might say that a thing of a type YYY is safe if it can only come from things of type XXX that are safe.

John Baez (Sep 07 2024 at 13:06):

For example a company might only want to buy some food if they're sure all ingredients in that food come from safe sources.

But this application works just as well, or even better, if we generalize fff to a relation from XXX to YYY. A relation from XXX to YYY is a subset

R⊆X×YR \subseteq X \times YR⊆X×Y

Any relation from XXX to YYY gives various maps PX→PYPX \to PYPX→PY and PY→PXPY \to PXPY→PX. In particular, we get two maps PY→PXPY \to PXPY→PX which we might call 'image' and 'dual image':

John Baez (Sep 07 2024 at 13:07):

  • y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y is in the image of S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X if some element x∈Xx \in Xx∈X with (x,y)∈R(x,y) \in R(x,y)∈R is an element of SSS.

  • y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y is in the dual image of S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X if every element x∈Xx \in Xx∈X with (x,y)∈R(x,y) \in R(x,y)∈R is an element of SSS.

John Baez (Sep 07 2024 at 13:09):

So you might be interested in the set of people who have at least one dog that's a poodle, or the set of people all of whose dogs are poodles. (Warning: if you have no dogs, all your dogs are poodles.)

John Baez (Sep 07 2024 at 13:11):

By the general yoga of category theory, we expect that these two constructions, defined using ∃\exists∃ and ∀\forall∀, are likely to be left and right adjoints, respectively.

This goes back to Lawvere's incredibly important observation in his 1967 paper Adjointness in foundations: ∃\exists∃ can be defined as a left adjoint, while ∀\forall∀ can be defined as a right adjoint!

Josselin Poiret (Sep 09 2024 at 09:20):

Ryan Schwiebert said:

but I still am struggling with the "interpret the unit and counit" part. I think it's because I don't quite get what the meaning of the relationship between predicates in X and predicates in X×Y given by p is supposed to mean.

fix p:X×Y→X p : X \times Y \to X p:X×Y→X the projection.
in logical terms, the operation f∗ f^* f∗ is known as weakening: it takes a predicate x:X⊢P(x) x : X \vdash P(x) x:X⊢P(x) and turns it into the predicate x:X,y:Y⊢P(x) x : X, y : Y \vdash P(x) x:X,y:Y⊢P(x). As you mentioned before, its left adjoint f∗ f_* f∗​ is the existential quantification, so turning x:X,y:Y⊢P(x,y) x : X, y : Y \vdash P(x,y) x:X,y:Y⊢P(x,y) into x:X⊢∃y:Y,P(x,y) x : X \vdash \exists y : Y, P(x,y) x:X⊢∃y:Y,P(x,y). Then, f∗f∗(P) f_*f^*(P) f∗​f∗(P) is x:X⊢∃y:Y,P(x) x : X \vdash \exists y : Y, P(x) x:X⊢∃y:Y,P(x).

Unit/Co-unit solution

In this case, we can prove that logically, x:X⊢(∃y:Y,P(x))⇒P(x) x : X \vdash (\exists y : Y, P(x)) \Rightarrow P(x) x:X⊢(∃y:Y,P(x))⇒P(x), which is the co-unit.
We can also prove that x:X,y:Y⊢P(x,y)⇒∃y′:Y,P(x,y′) x : X, y : Y \vdash P(x,y) \Rightarrow \exists y' : Y, P(x,y') x:X,y:Y⊢P(x,y)⇒∃y′:Y,P(x,y′), which is the unit.

John Baez (Sep 17 2024 at 04:18):

Has Leinster's book explained the ways you can compose functors and natural transformations:

  1. composition of functors
  2. vertical and horizontal composition of natural transformations
  3. left and right whiskering of a natural transformation by a functor

and the rules these operations obey? If you know these, I think this exercise is not too terribly hard: everything we need to get an adjunction between F∗F^\astF∗ and G∗G^\astG∗ should come from the corresponding bits of the adjunction between FFF and GGG.

John Baez (Sep 17 2024 at 04:22):

If you don't know this stuff, then you're in the position of having to make a bit of it up. It seems like that's what you're doing. In that case I'll just emphasize what I just said: each of the 4 features of the adjunction between F∗F^\astF∗ and G∗G^\astG∗ (the unit, the counit, and the two triangle identities) should come from the corresponding feature of the adjunction between FFF and GGG.

John Baez (Sep 17 2024 at 15:22):

Good! It sounds like you know all the rules. I hope you know how to draw Whiskering is indeed a special case of horizontal composition, so you can derive its rules from those for horizontal composition, but I believe it's so important for this problem that it's worth special attention.

For example:

  • F∗F^\astF∗ is composition with F ⁣:A→BF \colon \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{B}F:A→B: for any functor H ⁣:B→CH \colon \mathcal{B} \to \mathcal{C}H:B→C we have

F∗(H)=H∘F F^\ast(H) = H \circ F F∗(H)=H∘F

  • G∗G^\astG∗ is composition with G:B→AG: \mathcal{B} \to \mathcal{A}G:B→A: for any functor K ⁣:A→CK \colon \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{C}K:A→C we have

G∗(K)=K∘G G^\ast(K) = K \circ G G∗(K)=K∘G

  • F∗∘G∗F^\ast \circ G^\astF∗∘G∗ is composition with G∘FG \circ FG∘F:

(F∗∘G∗)(H)=H∘G∘F (F^\ast \circ G^\ast) (H) = H \circ G \circ F (F∗∘G∗)(H)=H∘G∘F

  • the counit ϵ∗ ⁣:F∗G∗⇒1\epsilon^\ast \colon F^\ast G^\ast \Rightarrow 1ϵ∗:F∗G∗⇒1 is whiskering with the unit ϵ ⁣:1⇒GF\epsilon \colon 1 \Rightarrow G F ϵ:1⇒GF

John Baez (Sep 17 2024 at 15:26):

I said each item of the adjunction you seek, G∗⊣F∗G^\ast \dashv F^\astG∗⊣F∗, came from the corresponding item of the adjunction you have, F⊣GF \dashv GF⊣G. But I was forgetting the contravariance: the counit of the adjunction you seek comes from the unit of the adjunction you have and the unit of the adjunction you seek comes from the counit of the adjunction you have. The triangle identities probably also get switched around in this way.

John Baez (Sep 17 2024 at 15:29):

To me it's very important to draw how the counit ϵ∗\epsilon^\astϵ∗ and unit η∗\eta^\astη∗ arise via whiskering from ϵ\epsilonϵ and η\etaη, because then - I believe - the whole proof can be carried out using pictures.

So one question is whether you know how to draw categories (dots), functors (arrows between dots), and natural transformations (globes between arrows).

If I were talking to you about this in person, I'd want all these entities like Φϵ\Phi \epsilonΦϵ to be drawn as 2-dimensional diagrams, and the things you want to showto also be drawn as diagrams. It's far harder to think about sort of argument using 1-dimensional strings of symbols. Unfortunately it's a pain to draw diagrams here (though some people use their cell phone to upload hand-drawn pictures, which is probably the fastest way).

For example, when you say Φϵ\Phi \epsilonΦϵ, I'm imagining an arrow Φ\PhiΦ whiskered onto a triangle, namely ϵ\epsilonϵ, which has one edge labelled 111 on top and two edges labelled FFF and GGG bottom. Does that match your picture?

(I hope you know you can draw a natural transformation ϵ:1→GF\epsilon : 1 \to G Fϵ:1→GF as a triangle in this way, though there are other equally fine drawing styles.)

By the way it's really useful to write natural transformations as ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ so we can instantly distinguish them from functors, drawn as →\to→. Natural transformations are arrows going between arrows, so they are 2-dimensional, so a bunch of us denote them by double arrows.

Ryan Schwiebert said:

I also meant to ask if my intuition that F′(αF)=(F′α)FF'(\alpha F) = (F'\alpha)FF′(αF)=(F′α)F holds (associativity of whiskering on the sides of a natural transformation.)

Yes, it's true. Whiskering with a functor is horizontal composition with an identity natural transformation, and horizontal composition of natural transformations is associative (as you should check), so whiskering is associative in this manner.

Todd Trimble (Oct 24 2024 at 03:44):

This isn't quite right; the comma category would have for its objects triples (X,Y,f:UX→UY)(X, Y, f: UX \to UY)(X,Y,f:UX→UY) where X,YX, YX,Y are pointed sets. The XXX and YYY could be two different sets, whereas the AAA that you're discussing is a single set.

You're not far off in your thinking, but comma categories or inserters would be more elaborate than is necessary. I don't want to give away the answer, but since objects involve just a single set AAA, as you say, an object might be describable as "a set AAA together with blah-de-blah".

Josselin Poiret (Nov 01 2024 at 21:19):

Ryan Schwiebert said:

Is it at least true that one can start with a transitive and reflexive relation, then symmetrize it, then take transitive closure, and conclude the final result is an equivalence relation?

yes.

In general, you would more directly say that you define a b a ~ b a b iff. there exists a path a→a1←a2→⋯→b a \to a_1 \leftarrow a_2 \to \cdots \to b a→a1​←a2​→⋯→b.

John Baez (Nov 01 2024 at 21:35):

@Ryan Schwiebert asked:

Is it at least true that one can start with a transitive and reflexive relation, then symmetrize it, then take transitive closure, and conclude the final result is an equivalence relation?

Yes. It's easy to check that:

  • the symmetrization of any reflexive relation is reflexive,
  • the transitive closure of a reflexive relation is reflexive,
  • the transitive closure of a symmetric relation is symmetric.

So when you take any reflexive relation, then symmetrize it, then take its transitive closure, you get an equivalence relation.

We can also 'reflexivize' any relation in the obvious way.

I believe that if you take any relation RRR, then reflexivize it, then symmetrize it, then take its transitive closure, you get the smallest equivalence relation containing RRR.

You can also just say "take the smallest equivalence relation containing RRR". This exists because the intersection of a collection of equivalence relations is an equivalence relation: it's the smallest equivalence relations containing RRR.

what I'd remark is that an equalizer in Set builds the subset of where two maps agree strictly, whereas a pullback can also choose how to make them agree up to a map on each side. You could then try to have two maps that don't agree strictly but could agree up to e.g. a permutation

Secondly, it struck me that "product vs binary-product" is a thing but "binary-equalizer vs (general) equalizer" (as in, a limit cone on a diagram with two nodes but some family of arrows indexed by a set going one direction between the two nodes) was not considered. Glad to see I'm not the only one thinking about it.

Does the multi-equalizer just not come in very handy?

Kevin Carlson (Jan 16 2025 at 19:15):

That’s right, if you throw out the terminal object you’ll get a category with all non empty finite limits, which is a perfectly reasonable kind of thing. And I agree the multi-equalizer doesn’t seem to come up naturally all that much, although wide pullbacks are more common! In generally you can move between pullbacks and equalizers given the presence of products, and pullbacks are often easier to reason about or seem more fundamental. Perhaps this is because formally they are a simply connected limit shape.

Ryan Schwiebert (Jan 17 2025 at 02:49):

Kevin Carlson said:

simply connected

Interesting... I'd like to ask in what sense this is meant. I remember simply-connected topological spaces and it looks like there is some other sense in geometry, at least, too.

Kevin Carlson (Jan 17 2025 at 04:14):

Yes, it's related to simply connected spaces in that there is a (non-directed) loops in the diagram indexing pairs of parallel arrows, unlike in the diagram indexing pullbacks. In fact the definition is that a connected category is simply category if its geometric realization has trivial π1\pi_1π1​ in the sense of homotopy theory.

John Baez (Feb 03 2025 at 04:53):

And maybe it's obvious, @Ryan Schwiebert, but when you find a counterexample to one of these claims you automatically get a counterexample to the dual conjecture in the opposite of that category, and when you get a proof of these claims for all categories, you automatically get a proof of the dual conjecture.

Ryan Schwiebert (Feb 13 2025 at 18:47):

Morgan Rogers (he/him) (Feb 14 2025 at 09:20):

That's right. To prove that a morphism of a particular type doesn't exist is a category constructed from a presentation (directed graph plus equivalence relation on paths with common start and end point) it's enough to show that there is no such path in the graph. Since your graph is acyclic (no loops) there are only finitely many paths in the first place, so it's straightforward.
On the other hand, I see how this can conflict at an intuitive level with results one encounters in categories obtained by other means such as Set, where it's enough for a morphism to satisfy certain properties in order for an inverse to be guaranteed to exist. Exercises like this are designed to show that such properties cannot be taken for granted.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) (Feb 14 2025 at 09:27):

Actually it strikes me that in this case there's another argument: if m where an iso then that would force a and b to be equal, since am=bm, so if they're not equal it can't be an isom

Graham Manuell (Mar 24 2025 at 11:26):

For what it's worth, what people generally care about when talking about the complexity of nested quantifiers is the number of 'alternations' between ∃\exists∃ and ∀\forall∀, since multiple adjacent ∃\exists∃ s (or multiple adjacent ∀\forall∀ s) can always be combined together into a single one. In this sense, the number of quantifiers isn't any worse than for continuity. Admittedly, I don't know if this actually helps with your problem of getting an intuition for this. But the point is that it isn't actually worse than something you already understand.

Josselin Poiret (Mar 24 2025 at 13:27):

i.e., there exists a cone, such that for any other cone, there is a cone morphism to it

Noah Chrein (Mar 24 2025 at 19:39):

Ryan Schwiebert replying

I've always found the notation that I first learned in kelly's enriched categories (3.1) more enlightening. When we are working with ordinary categories, and a functor acting as a "diagram" I→DCI \overset{D} \to CI→DC

C(c,lim⁡D)≅[I,C](    ∙    ,    C(c,D(−))    )C(c, \lim D) \cong [I, C](\;\; \bullet \;\;,\;\; C(c, D(−))\;\;)C(c,limD)≅[I,C](∙,C(c,D(−)))

C(c,lim⁡D)C(c, \lim D)C(c,limD) are maps into the limit c→lim⁡Dc \to \lim Dc→limD
[I,C](∙,  C(c,D(−))  )[I, C](\bullet,\; C(c, D(−))\;)[I,C](∙,C(c,D(−))) are "points in C(c, D(−))" which are natural transformations {c→ηiD(i)}i∈I\{c \overset{\eta_i} \to D(i)\}_{i\in I}{c→ηi​D(i)}i∈I​, i.e. "cones".

The isomorphism here is the universal property of the limit. That is, given {c→ηiD(i)}i∈I\{c \overset{\eta_i} \to D(i)\}_{i\in I}{c→ηi​D(i)}i∈I​ such that all the ηi\eta_iηi​'s commute we get the universal map c→lim⁡Dc \to \lim Dc→limD.

In general there is a deep connection between the definition of universal property and adjunctions. I learned this fact in Stammbach's Course in Homological Algebra Chapter II.8.

Kevin Carlson (Mar 24 2025 at 21:43):

This notation is particularly nice because it begs you to start wondering "what happens if I let that ∙\bullet∙ vary"?

David Egolf (May 01 2025 at 14:25):

I've not carefully been following this thread, so take what I say below with a grain of salt.

To my understanding you are considering an adjunction Γ⊣∇\Gamma \dashv \nablaΓ⊣∇ which involves a bijection Set(Γ(F),S)≅PSh(X)(F,∇(S))\mathsf{Set}(\Gamma(F), S) \cong \mathsf{PSh}(X)(F,\nabla(S))Set(Γ(F),S)≅PSh(X)(F,∇(S)) for any presheaf FFF on XXX and any set SSS. Here, PSh(X)\mathsf{PSh}(X)PSh(X) is the category of presheaves on XXX. Above it was stated that Γ(F)=F(X)\Gamma(F) = F(X)Γ(F)=F(X).

So our bijection can be rewritten as: Set(F(X),S)≅PSh(X)(F,∇(S))\mathsf{Set}(F(X), S) \cong \mathsf{PSh}(X)(F,\nabla(S))Set(F(X),S)≅PSh(X)(F,∇(S)). To try and understand ∇\nabla∇, let's consider this situation in the case where XXX is a topological space having exactly two open subsets.

Then a presheaf FFF on XXX involves:

  • two sets, F(X)F(X)F(X) and F(∅)F(\emptyset)F(∅)
  • a function :F(X)→F(∅):F(X) \to F(\emptyset):F(X)→F(∅)

And a morphism from one presheaf on XXX to another involves two functions that make a certain square commute. In particular, a morphism :F→∇(S):F \to \nabla(S):F→∇(S) involves a function :F(X)→∇(S)(X):F(X) \to \nabla(S)(X):F(X)→∇(S)(X) and a function :F(∅)→∇(S)(∅):F(\emptyset) \to \nabla(S)(\emptyset):F(∅)→∇(S)(∅).

The challenge then is to construct two such functions using a single function :F(X)→S:F(X) \to S:F(X)→S. I have a (possibly wrong!) hint on how to do this, spoilered below.

Maybe a helpful hint

We start with only one function, :F(X)→S:F(X) \to S:F(X)→S and we somehow need to make two functions. So maybe it would help if we built one of those functions from the one we start with, and we somehow constructed the other function to be degenerate / not using much information.

In that spirit, we might ask - if we need to have a function mapping to some set, and we want that function to be "as boring as possible", or involve "as little choice as possible" - then what might be a good set to map to?

Ryan Schwiebert (May 13 2025 at 12:56):

Well in case any of you find yourself in the same coaching situation again, here is what I think my problems were:

  1. I had to remind myself over and over again F(X)F(X)F(X) was just some set, not notation for the image of XXX under FFF. Not exactly a problem, but definitely a distraction.
  2. Forgetting to think of ∇S\nabla S∇S as a family of transformations, where each ∇SA\nabla S_A∇SA​ could potentially be any set, not one giant complicated one, and not necessarily dependent on its comrades. Intellectually I knew that but I definitely was not applying it correctly.
  3. If I could go back in time, my advice to my past self would have been something more like "You've already written down F(X)→SF(X)\to SF(X)→S and F(X)→F(A)F(X)\to F(A)F(X)→F(A). Now what is the least effort you can spend to make that into a commutative diagram?" Thinking of it as a sort of "minimum action" problem might have gotten me there too.

John Baez (May 13 2025 at 14:10):

The third point here sounds related to a general strategy in category theory: "take all the arrows you care about and put them into a single diagram, then add extra arrows that suggest themselves."

I haven't followed what you're saying, so this remark may be useless, but your last sentence makes me want to mention that there's always a god-given morphism

regardless of whether GGG preserves coproducts. So, you can compose any map
